newsitem.title: USA: U.S. attache sees S. Africa corn crop at 9.5 MMT.
newsitem.headline: U.S. attache sees S. Africa corn crop at 9.5 MMT.

text.p: An agricultural attache posted at the U.S. embassy in Pretoria forecast the 1996/97 South Africa corn crop at 9.5 million tonnes, up from a prior estimate but in line with the official USDA projection.
In a report dated Dec. 31 that was released in Washington this week, the attache also raised 96/97 corn exports to 2.3 million tonnes, up from 1.3 million tonnes earlier estimated.
On Dec 12, in its World Supply and Demand report, USDA estimated the 1996/97 South Africa corn crop at 9.50 million tonnes and pegged exports at 1.0 million tonnes.
The attache said export permits granted to the trade up to Dec 17 amounted to 712,000 tonnes of white and 761,000 tonnes of yellow corn for a total of 1.473 million tonnes.
The attache said the development of the new 1996 crop, especially when it will be dry enough to be harvested, would influence further corn export availability.
"The new crop should be available for export from June/July 1997 and the exportable surplus could be substantial," the attache wrote in the report.

The attache noted the 1996 corn crop will be the first crop in decades without some form of government marketing scheme. The Maize Board is due to withdraw from corn marketing by the end of April when the current marketing season ends.
